whoa architecture for databases and what we do is with a single click in our
console for configuring databases you can ask us to give you what we would call as a multi AZ configuration of a
database and what that does is it uses multiple data centers that we call availability zones in a single region so
let's say if you're in the East Coast region or the west coast region we will have multiple data centers that are
separated by distance enough by few miles from each other so that they are
flood flood zone separated power separated and not go down at the same
time but they have Layton sees of two to five milliseconds so that from an application and database perspective
they're ready next to each other and what we do when you ask for multi AZ database is that we give you a database
where there's a master in a single AZ and there's a standby replica which we keep synchronously replicated behind the
scenes between these data centers and we detect failures at our hardware level at
a software level at the AZ level no matter what happens in an AZ we will
detect it will fail over your database to you know take the standby and make it a master if your application is doing
retries it'll see a failure within 30 seconds the database will be back and this is something that even if you in
the old days where a large company you probably didn't have data centers in all parts of the world multiple data centers
in every region so you could do this of course if you're a small company that saw something impossible and this is one
of the reasons why production databases people run as multi easy so the goal should be if you have a database run it
on RDS if it's production database run it on multi a Z and the other point I

reads a second those are big numbers and you have to have a significant workload
to be able to consume that kind of a throughput but it's 5x of what you would get with my sequel or Postgres which is

example when you will do a write on this database this is obviously a my secure
comparable database so your application doesn't change in any way when you do a write behind the scenes we take that
right and we write it to six different copies because we are scared that we
might lose the data for you so we make six copies in fact we make two copies in every availability zone so that there's
no chance of having any durability issues and we also give you higher availability because not only can you
have a master but you can have up to 15 read replicas which can be in either the
same availability zone or other availability zones and these read replicas can act as failover target just
like I explained multi easy earlier these reader of leakers can act as your standby if you will for multi easy so if
your master fails we detect it and we failover to read replicas and you can set up fifteen read replicas in sequence
if you want to sort of the reader applica fails it goes to the next one and so on so it gives you high
ability is designed for 99.99% availability and and the other thing
that is very nice about it is because it is this shared storage architecture we
don't do replication and a database level we do it at the storage level what that does is that it really doesn't put
any you know any load on your master when we're doing the replication because it's happening behind the scene on this
distributed storage system and it also makes the lag between the master and the reader uplink are much smaller so it's
hundreds of milliseconds and sort of seconds and it just makes it give you much better experience and yesterday we

single region feature now the basic idea here is that just like we do the read replicas going into different different
AZ's and scale them out but we limit you to a single master with two hundred thousand writes we will now be able to
scale your write workloads and give you multiple masters in different
availability zones and this is the only my sequel post class comparable database service which does that with multiple
available reasons and there are two reasons why you would want to do it probably the most important reason is

so we designed our first database service and multiple services or data
warehouse services with that in mind and our design principle was we want to not
deal with single-digit terabytes we want to deal with para bytes to start with

thousand dollars a terabyte per year and that really resulted in I'll go quickly
to the service that I'm talking about here which is redshift so that resulted in our very first reinvent in 2012 we
announced a preview of Amazon redshift which we then took into GA in February of 2013 which is designed to be a para
byte scale data warehouse where you shouldn't have to throw away any of your data and it cost you one tenth and it's
a columnar system has you know this new architecture that's known as shared
nothing architecture we start with a single node and you can spin up up 228 nodes and with that you
can get up to 2 petabytes of compressed data we have customers that do as much
as 14 15 petabytes in the system and we use it a lot at Amazon and it's it's
something that is a fast growing service for us and then we have in this year in
2017 April we launched an extension to redshift called redshift spectrum which
is basically designed to expand the size of the data from terabytes to exabytes
in fact we did a demo at San Francisco summit where we ran a single query that
had to go through exabytes the data which you know if you're using presto will probably take you a few years of

data you gotta take compute to storage and so take storage to compute so we have an extension layer to redshift call
its spectrum which is a you know scale out multi-tenant layer that we use and
scale up based on the size of queries that you're sending to us which allows us to directly do queries on s3 and some

that's been using it they are dealing with para byte scale data the rate at which the data is coming into their

makes it easier for you to do this analytics we use s3 as data Lake for it

we are able to get the cheapest prices from ec2 for the amount of instance size
